column12: Title
Appareils pour bras artificiels pour permettre de saisir et de boutonner
Film roll support assembly for camera apparatus
column13: The invention relates to an assembly comprising a sleeve 12 having end shafts 20, 21, in order for the sleeve to be able to turn in a camera apparatus. A ratchet 28 is elastically mounted in a slot of the sleeve so that it projects beyond the outer surface and can engage in a slot 16 of a core 11 of a film roll. In this way, the core 11 is automatically centred on the optical axis 19 of the camera apparatus. Application to photographic apparatuses. <IMAGE>

column12: Improvements in Artificial Hand-grips.
column13: 120,302. Corley, Q. D. Dec. 31, 1917. Limbs, artificial. - Comprises a gripping-device attachable to an artificial arm and so jointed as to simulate the action of the wrist. A shank 1 is revolubly mounted in an artificial cuff 3 and receives the plates 4, 5 attached to the U-shaped body 6 of the rigid jaw 12, a bolt 8 being passed through to form a pivot. A clamping-nut 11 on the shank engages the top plate 4 to hold the rigid jaw in an adjusted position. The movable jaw 15 is hinged on a shaft 16 carried by a U-shaped rigidjaw member 6, a pair of springs 18 keeping the jaws normally open. Depending from a shaft 16<1> carried by the movable jaw 15 are spaced ratchet bars 19 connected by springs 22 to a lip on a yoke 25 pivoted on the shaft 16<1> and having a slotted bearing thereon. The ratchet bars 19 pass through openings 20 in the fixed jaw and engage a dog 21. To grip a plough handle or the like, the jaws are placed astride the handle, and the hinged jaw closed over it by the other hand. The fixed dog 21 engages the ratchet bars and holds the jaws closed. Additional pressure may be given by a screw 24 which bears on the rear end of the yoke 25. A quick release is provided by a cord 33 moved from the shoulder which causes a lever 32 to move a disengaging-plate 27, Fig. 3, to push the ratchet bars away from the dog 21 against the influence of a spring 30. Hooks project laterally from the outer end of the rigid jaw for use in lifting and pulling, one of them having a hook-point adapted for buttoning wearing-apparel, lifting strings, &c.

column12: Artificial Hand.
column13: 113,923. Corley, Q. D. Oct. 11, 1917. Limbs, artificial.-The fingers are adjustable into several positions by forming grooves 5 in their bases, into which a transverse loclcing-bar 6 is pressed by a spring 10. The bar can be retracted bv a cord 12. The thumb is pivoted on a stud 15 which carries a pulley segment 22 receiving the operating cord 23, and it is locked in the closed position by means of the ratchet 18 and pawl 19. For releasing the thumb, the cord 23 passes round a pulley 24 mounted on a dog 28. Tension of the cord causes the lip 33 of the dog to rotate the ratchet-wheel 29 and thereby the hexagonal cams 30 which depresses a sliding anglebar 31 having a shoe 32 bearing on the pawl 19. The pulley 22 is now free to be retracted by the spring 27 on relaxing the cord, the dog 28 riding back over the rack 29. In a modification, the fingers can be operated by a mechanism similar to that of the thumb.

APPAREIL DE TRAITEMENT COMPLET DE FILMS PHOTOGRAPHIQUES
column13:
L'INVENTION CONCERNE UN APPAREIL DE CONSERVATION, DE TRANSPORT, D'EXPOSITION ET DE DEVELOPPEMENT D'UN FILM PHOTOSENSIBLE.

ELLE SE RAPPORTE A UN APPAREIL QUI COMPORTE UN CHARIOT 26 PORTANT UN POSTE 20 DE TRANSPORT QUI CONTIENT UN ROULEAU DE FILM A EXPOSER. LA SECTION 20 DE TRANSPORT EST DEPLACEE SUR LE SOCLE 21 ET VIENT METTRE EN POSITION UN TRONCON DE FILM DANS LE PLAN IMAGE DE L'APPAREIL 17 DE PRISE DE VUES. LA SECTION 20 DE TRANSPORT ENTRAINE ENSUITE LE FILM EXPOSE VERS UN POSTE 71 DE TRAITEMENT. LA SECTION 20 DE TRANSPORT REVIENT ENSUITE EN POSITION INITIALE.

APPLICATION A LA FORMATION D'IMAGES DE GRAND FORMAT.

column12: Artificial Arms.
column13: 101,384. Corley, Q. D. April 5, 1916. Limbs, artificial.-An arm is provided with various means for grasping and manipulating objects and is designed so that the objects can be manipulated and the arm fitted on the person by people who have lost both hands. A forearm socket 1 is articulated to a divided sleeve 2 laced on the upper arm, and the laces are passed finally round friction hooks acting as locking-devices to prevent the lace from running back, thus enabling the wearer to draw the laces tight by holding the ends in his teeth. The lower end of the socket 1 carries a double clutch operated by the screw 15, which has an elongated head adapted to he rotated by the teeth or by friction against a table. The two clutch elements 13, 17 form part of a guided hollow rectangular frame 12. The element 17 co-operates with a slotted plate 16 and a socket 18 to hold the handles of knives, forks, &c., which are picked up by sliding the pointed end 19 of the socket underneath them. The element 13 co-operates with a fixed clutch element 10 to grasp a grooved stud 26 on the end of a combined hook and spring grasping-device, shown in Fig. 3. The upper member 21 is formed with long and short hooks 22, 23 respectively, which have hooked points 24 arranged as shown. The lower member 27 is spaced from the plate 21 and is provided with a depression 28 at an angle with its main axis. This member only extends laterally under the longer hook 22 and normally abuts against the under surface of the hook, except at the extreme end 29, which is curved downwardly and reduced to a fine edge to facilitate insertion under an object, such as a sheet of paper or a coin. By rotating a ratchet-wheel 30 carrying three cams 30<1>, the member 27 is alternately sprung downwards into the position shown in dotted lines in Fig. 1 and released again. Suitable objects may thus be grasped between the hook 22 and the member 27. Round objects, such as pencils, are additionally supported in the depression 28, as shown in dotted lines in Fig. 3. To operate the ratchet-wheel, the wearer first bends the forearm and pushes the pawl lever 31 in an anti-clockwise direction with his teeth. Then, on straightening the arm, the lever is moved in a clockwise direction through the medium of the cord 34 to operate the ratchet-wheel. The main hooks 22, 23 are used for lifting purposes, while the hooked points 24 are stated to be useful for buttoning clothes, opening purses, and tying and untying strings.

column12: Gripping and Buttoning Devices for Artificial Arms.
column13: 110,710. Corley, Q. D. May 17, 1917. Button-hooks and the like.-An artificial arm is provided with a buttoning attachment comprising a curved loop 24 carried by a sleeve 21 which is mounted upon a rod 17 and has quadrant notches 22 for engaging pins 23 to lock it against rotation in four angular positions. The rod is secured by a flynut 19 to the fixed jaw 2 of a gripping- device and can be slung sideways out of the way.

column12: ELBOW STRUCTURE
APPAREIL DE STOCKAGE, DE TRANSPORT ET D'EXPOSITION D'UN FILM PHOTOGRAPHIQUE
column13:
L'INVENTION CONCERNE UN APPAREIL DE STOCKAGE, DE TRANSPORT ET D'EXPOSITION D'UN FILM PHOTOGRAPHIQUE.

SELON L'INVENTION, LE FILM EST MAINTENU CONTRE UN PLATEAU TRANSPARENT PAR UNE FEUILLE SOUPLE DE MATIERE PLASTIQUE QUI, DU COTE DU FILM, A DES SAILLIES 38 DE FORME ALLONGEE QUI DELIMITENT ENTRE ELLES DES ESPACES POUR LA CIRCULATION D'AIR. UNE DEPRESSION EST APPLIQUEE A UNE EXTREMITE DE LA FEUILLE 37 ET SE PROPAGE PROGRESSIVEMENT SI BIEN QU'ELLE CHASSE TOUT L'AIR ET QUE LE FILM EST BIEN APPLIQUE CONTRE LE PLATEAU TRANSPARENT.

APPLICATION AUX APPAREILS DE TIRAGE PHOTOGRAPHIQUE.

column12: CERVICAL INTRA-LAMINA FUSION IMPLANT DEVICE AND METHOD
column13: A cervical intra-laminar fusion implant to be placed in cervical lamina includes a first lateral surface including a first arched edge, a second lateral surface positioned opposite to the first lateral surface, the second lateral surface including a plurality of posterior windows and a second arched edge, a top wall attached to the first lateral surface and the second lateral surface, the top wall having a plurality of teeth, a bottom wall positioned opposite to the top wall and attached to the first lateral surface and the second lateral surface, the bottom wall having a plurality of bottom teeth, a plurality of internal voids configured through the top wall and the bottom wall, and a connection mechanism connected to the top wall. The connection mechanism is positioned superior over the cervical lamina.

column12: SPINAL FLEXION AND EXTENSION MOTION DAMPER
column13: An orthopedic damper system and method to control the degree of flexion and/or extension motion of the mobile vertebral segment while providing additional stability to the spine. The damper system includes an anchor having a spring hitch, a spring coupled to the spring hitch, and a cap coupled to the spring. The anchor is adapted to connect to a spinous process. The spring includes an inner hollow area adapted to accommodate the spring hitch. The cap includes an opening connected to an inner cavity that is adapted to accommodate the spring and the spring hitch.

column12: ADAPTIVE SIGNAL RECEIVING METHOD AND APPARATUS
column15: BATTISTA, RALPH, NICHOLAS;;GROVES, QUENTIN, DURWARD;;TOW, JIMMY

column12: ADAPTIVE SIGNAL RECEIVING METHOD AND APPARATUS.
column13: Un récepteur de tonalité destiné à être utilisé dans un système téléphonique retrécit de manière adaptative sa gamme de sensibilité à l'amplitude, définissant des signaux de tonalité valables en fonction de l'appel par rapport à l'amplitude d'un premier signal de tonalité reçu lors d'un appel. Cette caractéristique d'adaptation aux gammes de signaux permet d'améliorer le rejet de l'écho du signal ainsi que l'élimination des bruits parasites. Un mode préférentiel de réalisation consiste en un processeur de signaux numérique programmé qui augmente le niveau des signaux de faible amplitude par rapport à l'amplitude du premier signal. Un mode alternatif de réalisation atténue de manière adaptative le niveau des signaux à l'arrivée avant la validation de ces signaux. Une autre amélioration des deux modes de réalisation permet un retrécissement supplémentaire de la gamme d'amplitude par rapport à tout signal successif d'un appel possédant une amplitude plus grande que celle de tout signal précédent dans le même appel.
column15: BATTISTA RALPH NICHOLAS;;GROVES QUENTIN DURWARD;;TOW JIMMY

column12: ADAPTIVE SIGNAL RECEIVING METHOD AND APPARATUS
column13: A tone receiver suitable for use in a telephone system and which adaptively narrows its amplitude sensitivity range defining valid tone signals on a per call basis in accordance with the amplitude of a first tone signal received on a call. The signal range adaptability improves signal echo rejection and spurius noise talkoff. A preferred embodiment is implemented by a programmed digital signal processor which increases the lower amplitude signal threshold in accordance with the amplitude of the first signal. An alternative embodiment adaptively attenuates the level of incoming signals before signal validation. A further improvement of both embodiments allows further amplitude range narrowing in response to any subsequent signal on a call which has an amplitude greater than that of any preceding signal in the call.
column15: BATTISTA RALPH NICHOLAS;;GROVES QUENTIN DURWARD;;TOW JIMMY

column12: Rod-to-Rod Connector
column13: A rod-to-rod connector assembly comprising a longitudinal member, which may be straight or S-shaped or have some other configuration; and a connecting member connected to a first end of the longitudinal member, wherein the connecting member comprises a pair of threaded opposed ends defining a channel therebetween. The assembly may further comprise a threaded blocking mechanism that engages the pair of threaded opposed ends of the connecting member. Preferably, the longitudinal member connects to only one of the opposed ends of the connecting member. The longitudinal member may comprise a first elongated portion comprising a first longitudinal axis; a second elongated portion comprising a second longitudinal axis; and a curved portion connecting the first elongated portion to the second elongated portion, wherein the first longitudinal axis and the second longitudinal axis are parallel to one another.
column15: REEDER JR RALPH F;;DURWARD QUENTIN;;FAIZAN AHMAD;;ABDELGANY MAHMOUD F
